intro: [WRONG START] Styrochaeton tenuinerve var. pubescens, commonly known as the hairy slender-veined sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant characterized by its slender, grass-like stems and narrow, linear leaves. It typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in wetlands, marshes, or along the edges of ponds. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, which are usually greenish or brownish in color. Its leaves are covered with fine, soft hairs, giving it the "hairy" appearance in its common name. This variety is often found in temperate regions and is valued for its ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils.
